block.p: INTERNATIONAL 3-25

China's Yellow River in Crisis With the sources of China's Yellow River threatened by climate change, and drought and pollution growing, the river is becoming a symbol of the dire state of the country's limited resources at a time of soaring economic growth. 1

Sunni Sheiks Denounce Cleric Sunni Arab sheiks from the volatile Anbar Province denounced a powerful Sunni cleric, calling him ''a thug'' for supporting Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia and urging the Iraqi government to arrest him. 22

Canada's Christian Right Grows The passing of legislation allowing gay marriage in Canada and the election early this year of Prime Minister Stephen Harper, a Conservative and an evangelical Christian, have galvanized conservative Christian groups to enter politics in the country as never before. 3

Journalists at Risk in Venezuela While the motives behind recent killings and other examples of aggression toward journalists remain unclear, human rights groups say threats and intimidation have become all too common in Venezuela. 14

Poland Faces Labor Shortage An estimated 800,000 people have left Poland since it joined the European Union in May 2004, creating a labor shortage so severe that the government may not be able to spend the money that the union is to begin sending in January for projects like improving roads and the water supply.16

Incentives for North Korea President Bush and his aides have signaled that they will offer new incentives for North Korea to give up its stockpile of nuclear weapons and technology, American officials said. But the offers would hinge on the North's agreeing to begin dismantling some of the equipment it has used to build an arsenal. 8
NATIONAL 26-37

Democrats Focus on Ethics Democratic House and Senate leaders, mindful that voters in the midterm election cited corruption as a major concern, say they are moving quickly to finish a package of changes for consideration as soon as the new Congress convenes. 1

Challenges for Bush Nominee Nominated by President Bush to replace Donald H. Rumsfeld as defense secretary, Robert M. Gates, will face challenges that dwarf even those he saw in the tumultuous last years of the cold war. 1

Glum Meeting for Conservatives For the last 20 years, the Federalist Society, a conclave of conservative lawyers, has flourished, even when there was a Democrat in the White House. But the recent election results may have given a jolt to the group. 26

Pledge to Keep 49ers Name In a strange political end run, two California politicians have pledged to introduce laws to prevent the San Francisco 49ers from calling themselves the 49ers if the team follows through on plans to relocate. 28
SPORTSSUNDAY SP1-16

Ohio Beats Michigan The No. 1 Ohio State Buckeyes beat the No. 2 Michigan Wolverines, 42-39. The victory secures Ohio State's undefeated regular season and its slot in the Bowl Championship Series title game. SP1
NEW YORK/REGION 39-45

Salaries Rose at Public Library Since 2003, when the New York Public Library declared itself in financial distress and unveiled an emergency campaign to raise $18 million in private money to deal with cuts in city and state financing , the compensation received by some of the institution's top officers has risen. 39
